CHAPTER 460 - OPERATION GENERALLY
460.01   Speed limits.
460.02   Negligent operation.
460.03   "U" turns.
460.04   Excessive noise; squealing tires; weaving.
460.05   Obstruction of traffic.
460.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Operation on right side of roadway - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 95-1/2, Secs. 11-701,
11-702
   Overtaking of vehicles - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 95-1/2, Sees. 11-703 et seq.
   Following too closely -see Ill. R.S. Ch. 95-1/2, Sec. 11-710
   Turning on highways - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 95-1/2, Secs. 11-801 et seq.
   Rules of right-of-way of vehicles - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 95-1/2, Secs. 11-901
et seq.,11-1205
   Operation upon approach of authorized emergency vehicles - see Ill. R.S. Ch.
95-1/2, Sec. 11-907
460.01 SPEED LIMITS.
   No person shall drive a vehicle on any street in the Village in excess of
twenty miles per hour, unless the speed limit is otherwise posted by a uniform
traffic sign.
460.02 NEGLIGENT OPERATION.
   No person shall operate a vehicle upon a public way negligently and without
due caution in a manner so as to endanger any person or property.
460.03 "U" TURNS.
   No operator of a vehicle shall turn such vehicle so as to proceed in the
opposite direction (making a "U" turn) on any through street or in any
intersection.
460.04 EXCESSIVE NOISE; SQUEALING TIRES; WEAVING.
   No person shall operate a vehicle in such a manner as to cause or produce
unnecessary loud, raucous, excessive or unusual noise by racing the motor, by
lack of a muffler or use of a muffler cut-out, by tire friction upon rapid
turning or weaving, by spinning of the wheels from a standing or slowly moving
position by sudden unnecessary motor acceleration, or by continuous unnecessary
sounding of a horn or other signal device.
460.05 OBSTRUCTION OF TRAFFIC.
   No person shall operate a vehicle or allow it to remain on any street in
such a manner as to form an unreasonable obstruction to the traffic thereon.
460.99 PENALTY.
(EDITOR'S NOTE : See Section
422.99 for general Traffic Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 462 - LICENSING
   EDITOR'S NOTE: This chapter was repealed by Ordinance 2025-10, passed April
28, 2025.
CHAPTER 464 - SAFETY AND EQUIPMENT
464.01   Riding on outside of vehicle.
464.02   Boarding or alighting from vehicle in motion.
464.03   Dangerous emissions.
464.04   Reflectors required for bicyclists and horsemen.
464.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Motor vehicle equipment - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 95-1/2, Secs. 12-100 et seq.
   Equipment safety compact - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 95-1/2, Secs. 12-101, 14-101 et
seq.
464.01 RIDING ON OUTSIDE OF VEHICLE.
   No person shall ride on a fender or running board or otherwise outside of a
vehicle.
464.02 BOARDING OR ALIGHTING FROM VEHICLE IN MOTION.
   No person shall board or alight from a vehicle while such vehicle is in
motion.
464.03 DANGEROUS EMISSIONS.
   No person shall operate a vehicle which emits dense smoke or such an amount
of smoke or fumes as to be dangerous to the health of persons or as to endanger
the drivers of other vehicles.
464.04 REFLECTORS REQUIRED FOR BICYCLISTS AND HORSEMEN.
   A person operating a horse or bicycle on any street in the Village after
dark shall wear upon his or her person, or attach to the horse or bicycle, a
reflector which reflects an amber color to the front and a red color to the
rear. The amber color shall be visible to oncoming traffic at a distance of not
less than 500 feet and the red color shall be visible at a distance of 200 feet
to traffic approaching from the rear.
464.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE : See Section
422.99 for general Traffic Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 466 - COMMERCIAL AND HEAVY VEHICLES
466.01   Trucks required to use right lane.

466.01 TRUCKS REQUIRED TO USE RIGHT LANE.
   On a roadway having four or more lanes for moving traffic and providing for
two-way movement of traffic, trucks shall use the lane farthest to the right
while traveling in either direction. The Village shall post appropriate signs
to make this provision effective.
466.02 TRUCKS PROHIBITED ON CERTAIN STREETS.
   No person shall drive a truck, except for the purpose of making a delivery
and then for one block only, on any street so designated by ordinance and
properly sign posted.
466.03 ENGINE BRAKING PROHIBITED ON DESIGNATED STREETS.
   No person shall operate any engine braking system (jackbrakes) on streets
designated by ordinance and properly sign posted except in the case of
emergency.
(Ord. 2004-34. Passed 10-13-03.)
466.04 DESIGNATION OF STREETS ON WHICH ENGINE BRAKING IS PROHIBITED.
   The operation of any engine braking system (jackbrakes) is prohibited,
except in the case of emergency, on the following streets within the Village 's
jurisdiction: Route 83 (Cal Sag Road) between 80th Avenue and 86th Avenue;
Route 7 (Southwest Highway) between 119th Street and 131st Street; and Route 45
(La Grange Road) between 122nd Street and 123rd Street, and between 125th
Street and 131st Street.
(Ord. 2004-34. Passed 10-13-03.)
466.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
422.99 for general Traffic Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)

468.01 ATTACHMENT TO OTHER VEHICLES.
   No person riding a bicycle, motorcycle or toy vehicle on a street shall
cling to or attach himself or herself or his or her vehicle to a moving vehicle
or wagon.
468.02 NUMBER OF RIDERS LIMITED.
   Not more than one person at a time shall ride on a bicycle propelled by
human power on a street. Not more than one person at a time shall ride on a
motorcycle except upon a seat permanently attached to the motorcycle to the
right or rear of the operator.

470.01 ABANDONED VEHICLE DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, "abandoned vehicle" means any motor vehicle or
other vehicle in a state of disrepair rendering the vehicle incapable of being
driven in its condition, or any motor vehicle or other vehicle that has not
been moved or used for seven consecutive days or more and is apparently
deserted.
(Ord. 1970-2. Passed 6-22-70.)
470.02 ABANDONMENT ON PRIVATE OR PUBLIC PROPERTY PROHIBITED.
   No person shall abandon a motor vehicle or other vehicle or part thereof on
any highway in the Municipality. No person shall abandon a motor vehicle or
other vehicle or part thereof on private or public property, other than a
highway, in view of the general public, anywhere in the Municipality, except on
the property of the owner or bailee of such abandoned vehicle. A motor vehicle
or other vehicle or part thereof so abandoned on private property may be
removed by or upon the order of the Chief of Police after a waiting period of
seven days or more has expired.
(Ord. 1970-2. Passed 6-22-70.)
470.03 NOTIFICATION TO POLICE DEPARTMENT; TOWING.
   When an abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or other vehicle
comes into the temporary possession or custody of a person in this State, not
the owner of the vehicle, such person shall immediately notify the Police
Department when the vehicle is in the Municipality. Upon receipt of such
notification, the Chief of Police shall authorize a towing service to remove
and take possession of the abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle
or other vehicle. The towing service shall safely keep the towed vehicle and
its contents and maintain a record of the two until the vehicle is claimed by
the owner or any other person legally entitled to possession thereof or until
it is disposed of as provided in this chapter.
(Ord. 1970-2. Passed 6-22-70.)
470.04 TOWING; COSTS.
   (a)   When a motor vehicle or other vehicle is abandoned on a highway in the
Municipality for ten hours or more, its removal by a towing service may be
authorized by order of the Chief of Police.
   (b)   When an abandoned, unattended, wrecked, burned or partially dismantled
motor vehicle or other vehicle is creating a traffic hazard because of its
position in relation to the highway, or when its physical appearance is causing
an impediment to traffic, its immediate removal from the highway by a towing
service may be authorized by order of the Chief of Police.
   (c)   When a vehicle is removed from either public or private property by
order of the Chief of Police, the owner of the vehicle shall be responsible for
all towing costs. Vehicles removed from public or private property and stored
by a commercial vehicle relocator or other towing service authorized by the
Chief of Police in compliance with this chapter, or at the request of the
vehicle owner or operator, shall be subject to a possessor lien for services
pursuant to the Labor and Storage Lien (Small Amount) Act (770 ILCS 50/1, et
seq.), as authorized by Section 4-203(g) of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS
5/4-203(g)). In no event shall such lien be greater than the rate or rates
established by the Illinois Commerce Commission pursuant to Section 18a-200(6)
of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/18a-200(6)). No lien authorized by
this section shall exceed two thousand dollars ($2,000) in its total amount,
nor shall such lien be increased or altered to reflect any charge for services
or materials rendered in addition to those authorized by this chapter and the
Illinois Vehicle Code.
(Ord. 1970-2. Passed 6-22-70; Ord. 2011-32. Passed 7-11-11.)
470.05 TOWING RECORDS; PAYMENT OF COSTS.
   When a motor vehicle or other vehicle is authorized to be towed away by
order of the Chief of Police:
   (a)   The authorization, any hold order and any release shall be in writing,
or confirmed in writing, with a copy given to the towing service.
   (b)   The Police Department shall keep and maintain a record of the vehicle
towed, listing the color, year of manufacture, manufacturer's trade name,
manufacturer's series name, body style, Vehicle Identification Number, license
plate year and number, and registration sticker year and number displayed on
the vehicle. The record shall also include the date and hour of tow, location
towed from, location towed to, reason for towing and the name of the Chief of
Police.
   (c)   The owner, operator or other legally entitled person shall be
responsible to the towing service for payment of applicable removal, towing,
storage, and processing charges and collection costs associated with a vehicle
towed or held under order or authorization of the Chief of Police. If a vehicle
towed or held under order or authorization of the Chief of Police is seized and
sold at public auction, any unpaid removal, towing, storage, and processing
charges and collection costs shall be paid to the towing service from the
proceeds of the sale. Any unpaid removal, towing, storage, and processing
charges and collection costs shall be paid to the towing service from the
Municipal Treasury. That payment shall not, however, exceed the amount of
proceeds from the sale, with the balance to be paid by the owner, operator or
other legally entitled person.
   (d)   Upon delivery of a written release order to the towing service, a
vehicle subject to a hold order shall be released to the owner, operator or
other legally entitled person upon proof of ownership or other entitlement and
upon payment of applicable removal, towing, storage, and processing charges and
collection costs.
(Ord. 1970-2. Passed 6-22-70; Ord. 2011-32. Passed 7-11-11.)
470.06 OWNERSHIP INFORMATION; RECORD SEARCHES.
   (a)   When the Police Department does not know the identity of the
registered owner, lienholder or other legally entitled person, the Police
Department will cause the motor vehicle registration records of the State to be
searched by the Secretary of State, for the purpose of obtaining the required
ownership information.
   (b)   The Police Department shall cause the stolen motor vehicle files of
the State Police to be searched by a communication directed to the State
Police, for stolen or wanted information on the vehicle. When the State Police
files are searched with negative results, the information contained in the
National Crime Information Center (NCIC) files will be searched by the State
Police. The information determined from these record searches shall be used by
the Police Department in sending a notification by certified mail to the
registered owner, lienholder and other legally entitled persons, advising where
the vehicle is held, requesting a disposition to be made and setting forth
public sale information. Notification shall be sent no later than ten business
days after the date the Police Department impounds or authorizes the impounding
of a vehicle, provided that if the Police Department is unable to determine the
identity of the registered owner, lienholder or other person legally entitled
to ownership of the impounded vehicle within a ten business day period after
impoundment, then notification shall be sent no later than two days after the
date the identity of the registered owner, lienholder or other persons legally
entitled to ownership of the impounded vehicle is determined.
(Ord. 1970-2. Passed 6-22-70; Ord. 2011-32. Passed 7-11-11.)
470.07 NOTIFICATION OF STATE POLICE.
   When the registered owner or other person legally entitled to the possession
of a motor vehicle or other vehicle cannot be identified from the registration
files of this State or from the registration files of a foreign state, if
applicable, the Police Department shall notify the State Police for the purpose
of identifying the owner of the vehicle or other person legally entitled to the
possession of the vehicle. The information obtained by the State Police shall
be immediately forwarded to the Police Department for notification of the
owner.
(Ord. 1970-2. Passed 6-22-70.)
470.08 REDEMPTION; CHARGES.
   Any time before a motor vehicle or other vehicle is sold at public sale or
disposed of as provided in this chapter, the owner or other person legally
entitled to its possession may reclaim the vehicle by presenting to the Police
Department proof of ownership or proof of the right to possession of the
vehicle. No vehicle shall be released to the owner or other legally entitled
person under this section until all towing and storage charges have been paid.
(Ord. 1970-2. Passed 6-22-70.)
470.09 DISPOSITION OF UNCLAIMED VEHICLES.
   (a)   Whenever an abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or
other vehicle, seven years of age or newer, remains unclaimed by the registered
owner or other person legally entitled to its possession for a period of thirty
days after notice has been given as provided in this chapter, the Police
Department shall cause it to be sold at public auction to a person licensed as
an automotive parts recycler, rebuilder or scrap processer under Chapter 5 of
the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/5-100, et seq.). Notice of the time and
place of the sale shall be posted in a conspicuous place, for at least ten days
prior to the sale, on the premises where the vehicle has been impounded. At
least ten days prior to the sale, the Police Department shall cause a notice of
the time and place of the sale to be sent by certified mail to the registered
owner, lienholder or other persons known by the Police Department or towing
service to be legally entitled to the possession of the vehicle. Such notice
shall contain a complete description of the vehicle to be sold and what steps
must be taken to reclaim the vehicle.
   (b)   If an abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed vehicle displays dealer
plates, notice under this section shall be sent to both the dealer and the
registered owner, lienholder or other legally entitled persons.
   (c)   In those instances where the certified notification specified in this
section has been returned to the Police Department by the postal authorities
because the addressee has moved or because the addressee is unknown at the
address obtained from the registration records of the State, the sending of a
second certified notice shall not be required.
(Ord. 1970-2. Passed 6-22-70; Ord. 2011-32. Passed 7-11-11.)
470.10 DISPOSITION WHEN OWNER UNKNOWN; ANTIQUE VEHICLES.
   (a)   When the identity of the registered owner, lienholder or other persons
legally entitled to the possession of an abandoned, lost or unclaimed vehicle
that is seven years old or newer cannot be determined by the means provided for
in this chapter, the vehicle may be sold or disposed of in the manner
authorized by this chapter without notice to the registered owner, lienholder
or other person legally entitled to the possession of the vehicle.
   (b)   When an abandoned vehicle that is more than seven years old is
impounded as specified by this chapter, it shall be kept in custody for a
minimum of ten days for the purpose of determining the identity of the
registered owner, lienholder or other legally entitled persons and contacting
the registered owner, lienholder or other legally entitled persons by U.S.
Mail, public service or in person for a determination of disposition; and for
the purpose of an examination of the State Police stolen motor vehicle files
for theft and wanted information. At the expiration of the ten day period,
without the benefit of disposition information being received from the
registered owner, lienholder or other legally entitled persons, the Chief of
Police shall authorize the disposal of the vehicle as junk or salvage.
   (c)   A vehicle classified as an antique vehicle, custom vehicle or street
rod, as defined by Section 1 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (65 ILCS 5/1-100, et
seq.), may, however, be sold to a person desiring to restore it.
(Ord. 1970-2. Passed 6-22-70; Ord. 2011-32. Passed 7-11-11.)
470.11 DISPOSITION RECORDS.
   When a motor vehicle or other vehicle in the custody of the Police
Department is reclaimed by the registered owner or other legally entitled
person, or when the vehicle is sold at public sale or otherwise disposed of as
provided in this chapter, a report of the transaction shall be maintained by
the Department for a period of one year from the date of the sale or disposal.
(Ord. 1970-2. Passed 6-22-70.)
470.12 DEPOSIT OF MONEYS.
   When a vehicle located in the Municipality is authorized to be towed away by
the Chief of Police and disposed of as set forth in this chapter, the proceeds
of the public sale or disposition, after the deduction of towing, storage and
processing charges, shall be deposited in the Municipal Treasury.
(Ord. 1970-2. Passed 6-22-70.)
470.13 LIABILITY FOR DAMAGES.
   A police officer, towing service owner, operator or employee shall not be
held to answer or be liable for damages in an action brought by the registered
owner, former registered owner or his or her legal representative, or any other
person legally entitled to the possession of a motor vehicle or other vehicle,
when the vehicle was processed and sold or disposed of as provided by this
chapter.
(Ord. 1970-2. Passed 6-22-70.)
470.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE : See Section
422.99 for general Traffic Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
TITLE EIGHT - PARKING
   Chap.
480. Parking Generally.
   Chap.
482. Municipal Commuter Parking Facility.
CHAPTER 480 - PARKING GENERALLY
480.01   Signs
480.02   Regulations at specific locations.
480.03   Overnight parking.
480.04   Snow emergencies.
480.05   Areas of prohibited parking.
480.06   Towing of vehicles in violation.
480.07   Sales on streets.
480.08   Parking on private property.
480.09   Parking near fire station.
480.10   Recreational vehicles.
480.11   Unattended vehicles.
480.12   Parking on 86th Avenue.
480.13   Parking on 81st Avenue. (Repealed)
480.14   Areas designated for permit parking.
480.15   Parking in spaces designated for handicapped persons.
480.16   Parking on 123rd Street.
480.17   Parking on Wolf Road.
480.18   Parking along US Route 45.
480.19   Parking on North Woodland Trail.
480.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to regulate standing or parking of vehicles – see Ill. R.S. Ch. 95-1/
2, Sec. 11-208
   State law re stopping, standing or parking – see Ill. R.S. Ch. 95-1/2, Secs.
11-1301 et seq.
   Abandoned motor vehicles – see TRAF. Ch.
470
   Off-street parking and loading – see P. & Z. Ch.
1282
   Municipal Commuter Parking Facility – see TRAF. Ch.
482
   Storage of inoperable or junk vehicles on residential lots – see GEN. OFF.
676.09
   Parking of refuse vehicles – see S.U. & P.S. 1060.09(c)
480.01 SIGNS.
   Council shall cause signs to be posted in all areas where parking is limited
or prohibited, indicating such limitations or prohibitions.
480.02 REGULATIONS AT SPECIFIC LOCATIONS.
   The Village may from time to time regulate, restrict or prohibit the
standing or parking of vehicles on specified streets or portions of streets in
specified areas. When signs or markings are in place giving notice of such
regulations, restrictions or prohibitions, no person shall violate or fail to
comply with such signs or markings.
480.03 OVERNIGHT PARKING.
   No person shall park a vehicle on a street for a period longer than thirty
minutes between 2:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. of any day, except vehicles being used
on emergency calls.
480.04 SNOW EMERGENCIES.
   No person shall park a vehicle on a public street at any time within eight
hours after a snowfall of two inches or more has occurred. Such eight-hour
parking restriction shall continue during snow removal operations until the
same are completed.
(Ord. 2009-28. Passed 11-9-09.)
480.05 AREAS OF PROHIBITED PARKING.
   No person shall permit a vehicle to stand at any time in any of the
following places, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or
in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control
device:
   (a)   In an intersection;
   (b)   In a crosswalk;
   (c)   On a bridge or viaduct, or in a subway or tunnel or in the approach
thereto;
   (d)   Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty feet of a
point of the curb immediately opposite the end of a safety zone;
   (e)   Within thirty feet of a traffic signal, beacon or sign on the
approaching side;
   (f)   Within twenty feet of an intersection or crosswalk;
   (g)   At any place where the standing of a vehicle will reduce the usable
width of the roadway for moving traffic to less than eighteen feet;
   (h)   Within fifteen feet of a fire hydrant;
   (i)   At any place where the vehicle would block the use of a driveway;
   (j)   Within fifty feet of the nearest rail of a railroad grade crossing;
   (k)   Within fifty feet of the driveway entrance to a Fire Department
station on the same side of the street as the Fire Department station;
   (l)   On a sidewalk or parkway; or
   (m)   At any place where official signs prohibit parking.
(Adopting Ordinance)
   (n)   In a "Parking by Permit Only" designated area as provided in Section
480.14, without evidencing a permanent or temporary permit on the vehicle so
parked.
(Ord. 1992-54. Passed 11-23-92.)
480.06 TOWING OF VEHICLES IN VIOLATION.
   (a)   Whenever a police officer finds a vehicle standing upon a street or
highway in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, or a vehicle
which has been parked in a public street or other public place for twenty-four
consecutive hours or longer, such officer is hereby authorized to move such
vehicle, or require the driver or other person in charge of the vehicle to move
the same, to a position off the paved or improved or main traveled part of such
street or highway.
   (b)   Whenever a police officer finds it necessary to remove a vehicle, as
provided for in subsection (a) hereof, and the owner or other person in charge
of such vehicle cannot be readily located or refuses to remove the vehicle, the
police officer is hereby authorized to have the vehicle removed to the nearest
public garage, parking lot or other place of safety by an authorized towing
service. Vehicles so towed shall be returned to the owner or operator thereof
after payment of the expenses incurred by the Village in removing and storing
such vehicles.
480.07 SALES ON STREETS.
   No person shall park a vehicle upon a street or right of way for the purpose
of displaying it for sale, or park a vehicle on a street or right of way from
which vehicle merchandise is peddled.
480.08 PARKING ON PRIVATE PROPERTY.
   (a)   No person shall park a motor vehicle on private property without the
consent of the owner of the property.
   (b)   No person shall park or store a commercial vehicle, not including
recreational vehicles as defined in Section
480.10 (a), upon residential property between 8:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. of the
next day, unless the vehicle is completely enclosed in a garage or other
accessory building located on such property.
480.09 PARKING NEAR FIRE STATION.
   No person, except a firefighter answering an emergency call, shall park a
vehicle on the north side of 123rd Street between approximately fifty feet east
of 89th Avenue and 500 feet east of 89th Avenue, opposite the fire station.
480.10 RECREATIONAL VEHICLES.
   (a)   Defined. As used in this section, "recreational vehicle" means and
includes a boat mounted on a trailer, a camp trailer, a travel trailer or any
trailer unit built or mounted on a vehicle or chassis, without a permanent
foundation, which may be legally driven or towed on a highway.
(Ord. 2001-13. Passed 3-12-01.)
   (b)   Parking on Private Property. The owner of a recreational vehicle may
park or store such vehicle on private residential property in the Village
subject to the following conditions:
      (1)   Not more than one recreational vehicle and one boat shall be stored
on any one residential lot.
      (2)   At no time shall such parked or stored recreational vehicle be
regularly occupied or used for living, sleeping or housekeeping purposes.
      (3)   If a recreational vehicle is parked or stored outside of a garage
or building, it shall be parked or stored to the rear of the front building
line of the lot and parallel to but not more than three feet from any garage or
building.
      (4)   Notwithstanding paragraph (b)(3) hereof, a recreational vehicle may
be parked temporarily anywhere on private residential property for loading or
unloading purposes.
480.11 UNATTENDED VEHICLES.
   (a)   No person shall leave a vehicle unattended while the engine of such
vehicle is running.
   (b)   No person shall leave a vehicle without a driver on a hill or incline
unless the vehicle is secured against moving.
   (c)   Whenever a police officer finds a vehicle unattended on a bridge or
causeway or in a tunnel, where such vehicle constitutes all obstruction to
traffic, such officer is hereby authorized to provide for the removal of such
vehicle to the nearest garage or other place of safety.
480.12 PARKING ON 86TH AVENUE.
   (a)   "Parallel Parking Only" signs shall be placed on the west side of 86th
Avenue beginning at a point thirty feet south of the south line of McCarthy
Road (123rd Street), and such signs shall be placed at intervals for a distance
of 120 feet, or four signs.
(Ord. 1976-11. Passed 10-11-76.)
   (b)   "Parallel Parking Only" signs shall be placed on the east side of 86th
Avenue beginning at a point thirty feet south of the south line of McCarthy
Road (123rd Street), and such signs shall be placed at intervals for a distance
of ninety feet, or two signs.
   (c)   A "No Parking From Here to Corner" sign shall be placed on the east
side of 86th Avenue at a point thirty feet south of the south line of McCarthy
Road (123rd Street).
(Ord. 1976-12. Passed 10-11-76.)
480.13 PARKING ON 81sT AVENUE. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 480.13 was repealed by Ordinance No. 2005-21, passed
June 13, 2005.)
480.14 AREAS DESIGNATED FOR PERMIT PARKING.
   Where it is determined that unique parking considerations directly affect
residents in a specific area, the Police Department is hereby authorized, upon
approval of Council, to place "Parking by Permit Only" signs in such areas.
Residents in such areas shall be given parking permits permitting parking on
streets in such areas for themselves and their guests. Vehicles displaying
these permits shall not be ticketed.
(Ord. 1992-54. Passed 11-23-92.)
480.15 PARKING IN SPACES DESIGNATED FOR HANDICAPPED PERSONS.
   It shall be illegal for anyone not having license plates indicating that the
operator is handicapped or a clearly identifiable handicapped sign posted in
the window of the vehicle, issued by an authorized governmental agency, to
park, stand or wait in a parking space or area designated for handicapped
parking.
(Ord. 1992-45. Passed 9-14-92.)
480.16 PARKING ON 123RD STREET.
   No person shall park any vehicle at any of the following described
locations:
   (a)   On the north side of 123rd Street, from the east right-of-way line of
89th Avenue to a point 149 feet east of the east right-of-way line of 89th
Avenue;
   (b)   On the south side of 123rd Street, from a point 251.3 feet west of the
west right-of-way line of Forest Glen Boulevard to a point 401.3 feet west of
the west right-of-way line of Forest Glen Boulevard;
(Ord. 1996-27. Passed 11-12-96.)
   (c)   On the north or south side of 123rd Street, from the west right-of-way
line of Wolf Road west to a point 500 feet west of the west right-of-way line
of Wolf Road; or
   (d)   On the north or south side of 123rd Street, from the east right-of-way
line of Wolf Road east to a point 500 feet east of the east right-of-way line
of Wolf Road.
(Ord. 2000-15. Passed 5-8-00.)
480.17 PARKING ON WOLF ROAD.
   No person shall park any vehicle at any of the following locations:
   On the east or west side of Wolf Road from the south right-of-way line of
123rd Street south to a point 500 feet south of the south right-of-way line of
123rd Street.
(Ord. 2000-15. Passed 5-8-00.)
480.18   PARKING ALONG US ROUTE 45.
   Parking shall be prohibited along US Route 45, (FAP Route 330-LaGrange
Road), State Section 103R-5, State Job Number C-91-146-11, from north of Creek
Road southerly to north of 143rd Street within the Village limits.
(Ord. 2013-30. Passed 7-8-13.)
480.19   PARKING ON NORTH WOODLAND TRAIL.
   No person shall park any vehicle on either side of North Woodland Trail on
school days, Monday through Friday, from 6:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.
(Ord. 2019-07. Passed 4-8-19.)
480.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
422.99 for general Traffic Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided. See
Section
422.04 for settlement schedule.)
   Whoever violates any provision of Section
480.16 or
480.17 shall be fined not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
(Ord. 1996-27. Passed 11-12-96; Ord. 2000-15. Passed 5-8-00.)
CHAPTER 482 - MUNICIPAL COMMUTER PARKING FACILITY
482.01   Establishment.
482.02   Use; commercial and heavy vehicles prohibited.
482.03   Supervision by Chief of Police.
482.04   Hours of operation.
482.05   Per diem parking fee.
482.06   Use of parking meters.
482.07   Spaces for handicapped persons.
482.08   Monthly commuter lot parking permits.
482.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to regulate standing or parking of vehicles - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 95-1/
2, Sec. 11-208
   State law re stopping, standing or parking - see Ill. R.S. Ch. 95-1/2, Secs.
11-1301 et seq.
   Parking generally - see TRAF. Ch.
480
   Parking in S-1 Districts - see P. & Z.
1273.13(c) 
   Off-street parking and loading - see P. & Z. Ch.
1282
482.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   An area acquired and maintained for the parking of motor vehicles is hereby
established as the Municipal Commuter Parking Facility and it shall be so
known.
(Ord. 1987-25. Passed 7-13-87.)
482.02 USE; COMMERCIAL AND HEAVY VEHICLES PROHIBITED.
   No person shall park any vehicle in the Municipal Commuter Parking Facility
in violation of any ordinance, contrary to the rules established by Council for
the use of such Facility or in any place or manner other than that designated
by Village authorities. No commercial or freight-carrying vehicle or trailer
shall be parked in a Village parking facility.
(Ord. 1987-25. Passed 7-13-87.)
482.03 SUPERVISION BY CHIEF OF POLICE.
   The Municipal Commuter Parking Facility shall be under the supervision of
the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 1987-25. Passed 7-13-87.)
482.04 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   The Municipal Commuter Parking Lot Facility shall be open from one-half hour
prior to the first train inbound to Chicago in the morning (4:54 a.m.) to one-
half hour after the last train outbound from Chicago in the evening (12:55
a.m.) (hereinafter referred to as a "Parking Day" for purposes of this Chapter
482), with parking in the Municipal Commuter Parking Lot Facility being
prohibited between 12:56 a.m. and 4:53 a.m. each day.
(Ord. 2006-42. Passed 11-13-06.)
482.05 PER DIEM PARKING FEE.
   It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle within the Municipal Commuter
Parking Facility without having paid the sum of one dollar and fifty cents
($1.50) for the privilege of parking within a parking space therein for a
Parking Day.
(Ord. 1987-25. Passed 7-13-87; Ord. 2005-02. Passed 1-24-05; Ord. 2006-42.
Passed 11-13-06; Ord. 2025-05. Passed 4-14-25.)
482.06 USE OF PARKING METERS.
   In any municipal parking lot in which meters or collection boxes are
installed, no person shall park any vehicle without first inserting the correct
fee in the meter or slot controlling the parking place used, or park for a
longer period than that covered by the fee deposited.
(Ord. 1987-25. Passed 7-13-87.)
482.07 SPACES FOR HANDICAPPED PERSONS.
   The Municipal Commuter Parking Facility shall have not less than two spaces
for handicapped persons, which spaces shall be clearly marked with the
international wheelchair symbol. No person who is not handicapped shall park
any vehicle in any such space at any time.
(Ord. 1987-25. Passed 7-13-87.)
482.08 MONTHLY COMMUTER LOT PARKING PERMITS.
   Monthly commuter lot parking permits may be purchased from the Village. The
following regulations shall be applicable to said monthly commuter lot parking
permits:
   (a)   The price for a monthly commuter lot parking permit shall be thirty
dollars ($30.00).
   (b)   Said monthly commuter lot parking permit shall be evidenced by a
sticker to be supplied by the Village, and displayed in the lower driver's side
corner of the vehicle's front window.
   (c)   Said monthly commuter lot parking permit shall entitle the vehicle to
which it is affixed to be parked in the Municipal Commuter Parking Facility on
any day of the week during the period of time covered by said monthly commuter
lot parking permit.
   (d)   The monthly commuter lot parking permit shall not entitle the owner of
the vehicle to which it is affixed to park in a particular parking space within
the Municipal Commuter Parking Facility, nor shall it guaranty that a parking
space will always be available within the Municipal Commuter Parking Facility.
      (Ord. 2006-42. Passed 11-13-06; Ord. 2011-14. Passed 3-28-11; Ord. 2025-
05. Passed 4-14-25.)
482.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
422.99 for general Traffic Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided. See
Section
422.04 for settlement schedule.)

CHAPTER 604 - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT

604.02   Resisting or obstructing police officers.

604.01 IMPERSONATING ATTORNEYS OR PUBLIC EMPLOYEES.
   No person shall falsely represent himself or herself to be an attorney
authorized to practice law, a peace officer, a public officer or a public
employee.
604.02 RESISTING OR OBSTRUCTING POLICE OFFICERS.
   No person shall resist or obstruct, or aid, abet or assist in resisting or
obstructing, the performance, by one identified to the person as being a peace
officer, of any authorized act within his or her official capacity.
604.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 608 - ANIMALS
608.01   Maximum number of dogs.

   CROSS REFERENCES

464.04

   Slaughtering animals - see GEN. OFF. 652.01(g)

1464.02
608.01 MAXIMUM NUMBER OF DOGS.
   No person shall own, keep, maintain or harbor more than four dogs at any one
time in the Village at the same location or residence. Therefore, no person
shall be issued more than four dog licenses for the same location or residence.
   This section shall not apply to dog kennels duly licensed by the Village.
(Ord. 1976-5. Passed 2-23-76.)
608.02 DOGS CAUSING DISTURBANCES.
   Upon a properly registered complaint, a dog that is causing a disturbance or
creating a nuisance shall be subject to impoundment by the Police Department or
the issuance of a citation to the dog's owner.
(Ord. 1976-5. Passed 2-23-76.)
608.03 DOGS AND OTHER ANIMALS RUNNING AT LARGE; IMPOUNDMENT.
   (a)   A dog found running at large in a street, on a public place or on
school grounds, or upon property belonging to a person other than its owner,
and not under the control of its owner, shall be considered stray and running
loose. Upon a properly registered complaint, such dog shall be subject to
impoundment by the Police Department.
   An attempt shall be made to return any dog so impounded to its rightful
owner. If this cannot be done promptly, then such dog shall be impounded. After
five days, it may be destroyed or otherwise disposed of. If the owner of an
impounded dog claims such dog, the owner shall have to submit proper evidence
of ownership and exhibit a current, duly issued license for such dog.
   In addition to any other fine or penalty imposed under this Code for a
violation of any of the provisions of this section, the Police Department is
hereby authorized and directed to assess a charge of twenty-five dollars
($25.00) per day for each day that a dog is impounded.
   If a tranquilizer gun is used to apprehend a stray or vicious dog which
cannot be captured by normal means, the Village and its agents shall not be
responsible if the animal succumbs as a result of the use of the tranquilizer
gun.
   (b)   No person shall permit any poultry, bovine, swine, sheep or goat to
run at large in the Village.
(Ord. 2008-11. Passed 3-24-08.)
608.04 DOG LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall own, harbor or keep a dog in the Village unless the person
obtains an annual license therefor. Such license shall be obtained by July 1
unless the dog Is less than four months old on such day, in which case a
license shall be obtained when the dog reaches the age of four months. A person
who acquires a dog after July 1 shall obtain a license within thirty days from
the time of acquisition or at the time the dog reaches the age of four months.
608.05 LICENSE APPLICATION; RABIES INOCULATION.
   Application for a dog license shall be made with the Department of Accounts
and Finances. At the time of such application, the owner shall provide the
following:
   (a)   The name and address of the owner of the dog;
   (b)   The name, age, sex, breed and description of the dog to be licensed;
and
   (c)   A certificate of inoculation for rabies from the County Health
Department bearing a date within one year prior to the date of application.
(Ord. 2008-11. Passed 3-24-08.)
608.06 LICENSE FEES; TAGS.
   (a)   The fee for a dog license shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per year for
each dog. All licenses shall be for a period of one year, beginning on July 1st
of each year and expiring on June 30th of the following year. No prorating of
the license fee shall be made relative to any license purchased after the start
of the license year.
   (b)   The dog license shall be evidenced by a small metal tag to be issued
to the owner of each properly licensed dog upon the payment of the license fee.
Such license tag shall bear the name of the Village, an identifying license
number and the license year, and shall be securely attached to the collar or
harness of such dog. A replacement tag shall be issued upon payment of a fee of
five dollars ($5.00).
(Ord. 2008-11. Passed 3-24-08.)
608.07 REGISTER OF DOGS.
   The Department of Accounts and Finances shall keep a complete register or
file for all licensed dogs describing such dogs by name, age, sex, breed and
color and showing the name and address of the owners or keepers thereof, as
given, and the numbers of the Village license tags.
(Ord. 2008-11. Passed 3-24-08.)
608.08 ATTACHMENT AND REMOVAL OF TAGS.
   Every owner or keeper of a dog in the Village shall keep the license tag
required by this chapter securely attached to a collar or harness fastened
around the neck or body of such dog at all times when such dog is off the
premises of the licensed owner or keeper. No person, other than the owner or
keeper, his or her agent or a member of the Police Department or its agent,
shall remove a license tag from a dog.
608.09 TRANSFER OF LICENSES.
   Whenever the ownership or possession of a properly licensed dog changes to a
new owner who resides within the Village, said new owner shall apply for a
transfer of the current license issued pursuant to this chapter. The fee for
such transfer of the license shall be five dollars ($5.00).
(Ord. 2008-11. Passed 3-24-08.)
608.10 DOGS IN PUBLIC PLACES; LEADER DOGS.
   No person shall permit a dog, even though on a leash, to enter a public
building, restaurant, office, store, grocery, coffee shop, ice cream parlor,
soft drink parlor or any store or shop for the sale of food, except any shop
for the sale of animal pets, during the time that such places are open for the
use of the public.
   This section shall not apply to dogs leading blind and/or deaf persons or to
law enforcement dogs.
608.11 ANIMALS DISTURBING THE PEACE.
   No person shall harbor or keep a dog or any other animal which disturbs the
peace by making constant loud noises at any time of the day or night.
(Ord. 1976-5. Passed 2-23-76.)
608.12 DANGEROUS ANIMALS RUNNING AT LARGE.
   (a)   No person shall permit a dangerous or vicious animal of any kind to
run at large in the Village.
   (b)   The members of the Police Department may kill such a dangerous or
vicious animal when it is necessary for the protection of another animal or a
person.
(Ord. 1976-5. Passed 2-23-76.)
608.13 POISONING ANIMALS.
   No person shall place, leave or expose, in any place accessible to birds,
fowl, dogs, cats or other domestic or wild animals, with the intent to kill or
harm such birds, fowl or other animals, any poisonous substance or ingredient.
(Ord. 1976-5. Passed 2-23-76.)
608.14 HABITUALLY STRAY DOGS.
   If a dog is found running at large, as provided in Section
608.03, and returned to its owner, no fee shall be assessed for the first
violation if the dog is returned within one hour. However, if a dog has been
returned more than once in a six-month period by police officers, such police
officers may issue a citation to the owner for having an habitually stray dog.
(Ord. 1976-5. Passed 2-23-76.)
608.15 CRUELTY.
   No person shall cruelly treat an animal in the Village in any way. No person
shall inhumanely beat, underfeed, overload, abandon or wantonly destroy an
animal in any way.
608.16 ANIMALS LEFT UNATTENDED.
   No person shall leave a horse or other draft animal unattended in a street
without having such animal securely fastened.
608.17 HUNTING.
   No person shall hunt game or wild fowl in the Village.
608.18 NUISANCE CONDITIONS PROHIBITED.
   No person shall cause or permit any place where any animal or fowl is or may
be kept to become unclean or unwholesome. No person shall cause or permit the
excrement of any animal to accumulate, thereby causing noxious odors or unclean
or unwholesome conditions. No person shall dump such animal waste on any
neighboring property not owned by the owner or keeper of the animal.
608.19 LEGHOLD TRAPS.
   No person shall use or permit the use of any leghold animal trap or similar
device with spring-activated jaws of the type used for the trapping of fur-
bearing animals, which is capable of inflicting cruelty upon dogs, cats or
other animals or which constitutes a hazard to small children.
(Ord. 1983-10. Passed 8-22-83.)
608.20 EQUINE ANIMAL REGULATIONS.
   (a)   Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) below, the following
limitations shall apply to the housing of equine animals on property zoned for
residential purposes:
      (1)   The housing of equine animals on a parcel of property of less than
21,780 square feet (one-half acre) in area is prohibited.
      (2)   Up to two equine animals may be housed on a parcel of property of
at least 21,780 square feet (one-half acre) in area, with one additional equine
animal being allowed for each additional 10,890 square feet (one-quarter acre)
in area above the initial 21,780 square feet (one-half acre).
   (b)   Where the housing of equine animals on property zoned for residential
purposes is not in compliance with subsection (a) above on the effective date
of this section (July 8, 2004), said non-compliance may continue, but may not
be expanded (the total number of equine animals housed on the property may not
be increased). The following parcel of property has been specifically
identified by Village staff, as of the effective date of this section, as being
non-compliant, and, as such, may continue to house the number of equine animals
indicated even after the effective date of this section: 11500 West 123rd
Street - three equine animals.
   (c)   In the case of the birth of an equine animal which causes a parcel of
property to become non-compliant with subsection (a) above, the owner(s) and
occupant(s) of said parcel of property shall have six months from the date of
said birth to bring the parcel of property back into compliance with subsection
(a).
   (d)   Excrement produced by equine animal(s) shall be removed from a parcel
of property zoned for residential purposes, by the owner(s) or occupant(s) of
said parcel of property, no less often than once per week (once every seven
days), through the use of the Village's refuse hauler or by alternate refuse
hauling means.
   (e)   Where a parcel of property has been granted a special use which allows
for an equine animal stable, said parcel of property shall be exempt from the
provisions of this section.
(Ord. 2004-35. Passed 6-28-04.)
608.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 652 - NUISANCES
652.01   Specific nuisances enumerated.
652.02   Abatement by Mayor.

   CROSS REFERENCES

652.01 SPECIFIC NUISANCES ENUMERATED.
   Conditions or actions declared to be nuisances in the Village include, but
are not necessarily limited to, the following:
   (a)   Violations of Technical Codes and Ordinances. To violate or fail to
comply with the Building and Housing Code or the Zoning Code, or to permit the
condition of any premises declared by the Mayor to be a nuisance;
   (b)   Peace Disturbances.  To disturb the public peace, as follows:
      (1)   For a person owning or in possession, charge or control of any
building or premises, to use the same, or permit the use of the same, or rent
the same to be used, for any business or employment, or for any purpose of
pleasure or recreation, if such use, from its noise or boisterous nature,
disturbs or destroys the peace of the neighborhood in which such building or
premises is situated, or is dangerous or detrimental to health;
(Adopting Ordinance)
      (2)   To conduct commercial building operations during weekdays between
the hours of 8:00 p.m. or sunset (whichever is earlier) and 7:00 a.m. on the
day following; and between the hours of 5:00 p.m. Saturday and 7:00 a.m. on
Monday or on Memorial Day, Labor Day, New Years Day, Christmas Day,
Independence Day or Thanksgiving Day.
      (3)   To operate heavy equipment or other apparatus, including, but not
limited to, mechanically powered tools (i.e. power saws, drills, hammers,
sanders or grinders), all of which are attended with loud and disturbing noises
between the hours of 8:00 p.m. or sunset (whichever is earlier) and 7:00 a.m.
on the day following and between the hours of 5:00 p.m. on Saturday and 7:00
a.m. on Monday or on Memorial Day, Labor Day, New Years Day, Christmas Day,
Independence Day or Thanksgiving Day.
      (4)   Property owners and their immediate families shall be exempt from
the provisions of paragraphs (b)(2) and (3) hereof, except that no property
owner doing his or her own building, electrical or plumbing work, or performing
any part of building construction, shall operate or permit to be operated and
heavy equipment or apparatus or any mechanically-powered hand tool, power saw,
drills, hammer, sanders, grinders or similar powered tools in residential areas
between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. of the following day of weekdays
and before 10:00 a.m. or after 6:00 p.m. on Sunday, so as to cause a
disturbance across a residential real property line. Sunday hours shall be in
effect on all holidays as defined in paragraphs (b)(2) and (3) hereof.
      (5)   No heavy construction equipment shall be used or operated after 6:
00 p.m. of any evening on days when such use or operation is otherwise
permitted.
      (6)   No roads shall be blocked by anyone doing construction work prior
to 8:00 a.m. on days when construction work is otherwise permitted.
      (7)   Necessary construction work or repairs are authorized in the case
of a bonafide emergency to prevent damage to the building or to insure the
safety of occupants therein. A variance from the provisions of this subsection
may be authorized by the Building Department under emergency conditions where
the granting of the variance will not adversely affect the health, safety or
welfare of the surrounding residents.
(Ord. 1993-37. Passed 9-13-93.)
   (c)   Use of Building for Offensive Business. To erect, continue or use any
building or other place for the exercise of any trade, employment or
manufacture in the Village which, by occasioning noxious exhalations, offensive
smells or otherwise, is offensive or dangerous to the health of individuals or
the public;
   (d)   Smoke. To permit any dense smoke to come or be emitted from any fire,
chimney, engine, oil burner or other agency in the Village;
   (e)   Offensive Smells. To negligently conduct any business or use any
premises so as to create an offensive smell that may taint the air and render
it unwholesome or disagreeable in the neighborhood;
   (f)   Offensive Animal Pens. To own, use or keep any yard, pen, place,
railroad car or premises, in or upon which cattle or other animals are confined
or kept, so as to be offensive to those residing in the vicinity or an
annoyance to others;
   (g)   Slaughtering. To slaughter or kill any bovine, hog, sheep, horse, fowl
or other animal, or to keep, maintain or use in the Village any house or place
in which the business of slaughtering any of such animals may be carried on;
   (h)   Failure to Remove Waste. To cause or suffer the carcass of any animal
or vegetable matter, slops, swill, suds, garbage, filth, stable drippings or
offal or noisome substance of any kind to be collected or deposited or to
remain in any place in the Village to the prejudice of others;
   (i)   Pollution of Water. To corrupt, render unwholesome or injure the water
of any drinking hydrant, spring, stream, pond or lake to the injury and
prejudice of others;
   (j)   Dumping Polluted Water. To cause any water which contains any soap,
detergent, washing compound, solvent or effluent from any sewage treatment
system to be dumped into any ditch, gutter, ravine or watercourse;
   (k)   Obstruction of Watercourses; Stagnation of Water. To obstruct any
watercourse, ravine or gutter, or to cause water to stagnate therein, or to
permit foul or stagnant water to stand upon any premises to the prejudice of
others;
   (l)   Deposit of Offal in Watercourse. To throw or deposit, or cause to be
thrown or deposited, any offal or other offensive matter, or the carcass of any
animal, into any watercourse, pond, spring or well in the Village;
   (m)   Unsightly Yards and Premises. To permit, maintain or cause an
unsightly yard or premises, where there is an accumulation or deposit of
vehicles, equipment, material of any nature, waste or earth;
   (n)   Accumulation of Junk. To cause or suffer debris, junk, etc., to be
collected or deposited or to remain on the premises in such quantities and in
such condition as to increase breeding of, and refuse for, rodents, vermin or
any other undesirable nuisance;
   (o)   Premises in Filthy Condition. For a person to keep or suffer to be
kept in a foul, offensive, nauseating or filthy condition, any chicken coop,
cow house, stable, cellar, vault, drain, privy, sewer, septic or other sewage
disposal system or sink upon any premises belonging to or occupied by such
person, or any railroad car, building, yard, grounds or premises belonging to
or occupied by him or her;
   (p)   Accumulation of Vegetation. To cause or suffer grass, leaves,
underbrush or other combustible matter to be collected or deposited or to
remain on the premises in such quantities and in such condition as to
materially increase the danger to the property of others from forest or other
fires;
   (q)   Placing of Garbage Cans. To cause or suffer garbage cans or containers
to remain on parkways, walks, driveways or front yards;
   (r)   Dumping. To deposit or dump, anywhere within the Village or within one
mile of the Municipal limits, any nightsoil, refuse, garbage, offal or other
material or liquid which emits or may emit nauseating odors or fumes or which
attracts or may attract rodents, vermin or insects known to carry or transmit
disease or known to impair or endanger the health of the inhabitants of the
community;
   (s)   Privies. To erect or maintain a privy in the Village, except as
otherwise permitted and regulated;
   (t)   Obstruction of Streets. To obstruct or encroach upon public highways,
private ways, streets, alleys or commons;
   (u)   Common Law and State Nuisances. To commit an offense which is a
nuisance according to the common law of the land or the statutes of the State;
   (v)   Littering. For a person to dump, deposit, drop, throw, discard or
leave, or cause or permit the dumping, depositing, dropping, throwing,
discarding or leaving, of litter upon any public or private property, not owned
by the person, in the Village, or upon or into any river, lake, pond, stream or
other body of water in the Village, unless
      (1)   The litter is placed into a receptacle or other container intended
by the owner or person in lawful possession of that property for the deposit of
litter;
      (2)   The person is acting under the direction of proper public officials
during special clean-up days; or
      (3)   The person is lawfully reacting to an emergency situation where
health and safety are threatened;
   (w)   Deteriorating Property. To allow any building or structure, or the
condition of one's property, to deteriorate to such a state that it becomes a
potential hazard which could endanger the person or property of another or
become the breeding ground or habitat of dangerous, unpleasant, unclean or
disease-ridden animals, vermin or other pests;
   (x)   Obstruction of Sewers. To stop or obstruct the passage of water In any
street or public ditch, public sewer, culvert, water pipe, hydrant or drain
laid or placed in the Village;
   (y)   Open Excavations. To leave open a cellar door, vault, well, cistern,
excavation or other similar hole without securing or protecting the same so as
to prevent persons or animals from falling therein;
   (z)   Chicken Coops. To fail to construct or maintain any chicken coop, as
defined in Section
1260.08(23a) of this Code, in compliance with Section
1286.06(e) of this Code, or fail to maintain any chicken coop in compliance
with the following guidelines:
      (1)   No more than five chickens shall be allowed on a lot of less than
one acre in size.
      (2)   For lots that are one acre or more in size, one chicken shall be
allowed for every one-tenth acre (ten chickens per acre); provided, however,
not more than twenty-five chickens shall be allowed, regardless of the size of
the lot.
      (3)   No more than one rooster shall be allowed on a lot of five acres or
more. All roosters must be confined inside the coop between the hours of 6:
00p.m. and 9:00a.m.
      (4)   All feed for chickens and/or roosters shall be kept in rodent-proof
containers.
      (5)   All chickens and/or roosters kept in the Village shall be kept in a
pen, coop, or building which shall be maintained in such a manner so as to
protect them from predators and trespassers.
      (6)   All pens, coops, buildings, yards, or enclosures for chickens and/
or roosters shall be kept clean, sanitary, and free from all refuse. Such areas
shall be thoroughly cleaned at least once every seven days and all refuse shall
be disposed of in a clean and sanitary fashion.
      (7)   In the event that the owner of property, upon which chickens and/or
roosters are being kept as of the effective date of this subsection (September
22, 2014), certifies to the Village the number of chickens and/or roosters so
being kept, and the Village staff verifies same, said owner shall be allowed to
keep chickens and roosters on the property, in the numbers so certified and
verified, notwithstanding the provisions of subsections (1), (2), and (3)
above.
      (8)   Where a special use has been granted for farming then the
provisions of subsections (1), (2), and (3) above shall not apply; and
   (aa)   Animal Fights and Contests Prohibited. No person shall promote,
stage, hold, manage, conduct, or carry on any animal fight, or train any animal
for the purpose of an animal fight or any other type of contest, game, or fight
of a similar nature, nor any simulated version of same that involves baiting or
inciting an animal to fight.
(Ord. 2014-21. Passed 9-22-14.)
652.02 ABATEMENT BY MAYOR.
   Whenever a nuisance exists or is found on any premises in the Village,
whether or not such nuisance is one specifically enumerated in these Codified
Ordinances, the Mayor is hereby authorized, at his or her discretion, to cause
the same to be summarily abated in such a manner as he or she may direct, at
the expense of the party permitting or maintaining the nuisance.
652.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE : See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 656 - OFFENSES RELATING TO PERSONS

656.02   Parent's responsibility for minor.
