1246.01 CONFORMITY TO COMPREHENSIVE PLAN; OTHER CONSIDERATIONS.
   The subdivision of land, including the arrangement, character, extent,
width, grade and location of all streets, alleys or other land to be dedicated
for public use, shall conform to the Comprehensive Plan of the Village, as
approved and adopted by Council and other responsible governmental bodies, and
shall be considered in its relation to existing and planned streets, to
topographical conditions, to public convenience and safety and in its
appropriate relation to the proposed uses of the area to be served.
1246.02 MINIMUM STREET STANDARDS.
   (a)   All rights of way shall conform to the following minimum dimensions:
      (1)   Primary or major streets shall conform to the Official Village Map
and in no instance be less than 100 feet.
      (2)   Secondary or collector streets shall be eighty feet.
      (3)   Minor streets shall be sixty-six feet.
      (4)   Cul-de-sacs shall have a radius of not less than fifty feet.
      (5)   Crosswalkways shall be ten feet.
      (6)   Utility easements shall be sixteen feet.
   (b)   Minor streets shall be so laid out that their use by through traffic
will be discouraged.
   (c)   Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than 125 feet shall be
avoided.
   (d)   Clear visibility, measured along the centerline of the street, shall
be provided for at least 300 feet on all primary streets, 200 feet on secondary
streets and 100 feet on all other streets.
   (e)   It must be evidenced that all street intersections and confluences
encourage safe traffic flow.
   (f)   Alleys are not permitted, except where deemed necessary, and at the
discretion of the Plan Commission and Council.
   (g)   The maximum length of a cul-de-sac shall be not more than 500 feet
measured along the centerline from the intersection at its origin through the
center circle to the end of the right-of-way. Each cul-de-sac shall have a
terminus of nearly circular shape with a minimum diameter of 100 feet.
   (h)   Half streets are prohibited.
   (i)   No street names may be used which will duplicate or be confused with
the names of existing streets within the jurisdiction of these Regulations.
Existing street names must be projected wherever possible.
   (j)   All requirements of
Chapter 1462 of the Building and Housing Code (Development in Flood Hazard
Areas) must be complied with.
1246.03 EASEMENTS.
   (a)   Easements across lots or centered on rear or side lot lines shall be
provided for utilities where necessary and shall be at least sixteen feet wide.
Proper continuity for utilities shall be maintained from block to block.
   (b)   Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway,
channel or stream, there shall be provided a storm water easement or drainage
right of way conforming substantially to the lines of such watercourse, and
such further width or construction, or both, as will be adequate for proper
drainage. Parallel streets or parkways may be required in connection therewith.
1246.04 BLOCK STANDARDS.
   (a)   No specific rule concerning the shape of blocks is made, but blocks
must fit easily into the overall plan of the subdivision and their design must
evidence consideration of topographical features, lot planning, traffic flow
and public areas.
   (b)   Blocks intended for commercial and industrial use must be designated
as such, and the plan must show off-street areas providing for parking, loading
docks and such other facilities as may be required by the Zoning Code.
1246.05 LOT STANDARDS.
   (a)   The minimum lot dimension and area shall conform to the requirements
of the Zoning Code for residential development.
   (b)   Building lines shall be maintained on both streets on corner lots.
   (c)   Building lines shall conform to the front yard provisions of the
Zoning Code.
   (d)   All lots shall abut a publicly dedicated street for a minimum distance
of thirty feet or abut a permanent easement for access. Any such permanent
access easements shall comply with the following standards:
      (1)   If recorded prior to April 25, 1960, the easement width may be less
than twenty-five feet wide.
      (2)   If recorded between April 25, 1960 and June 23, 2003, the easement
shall be at least twenty-five feet wide.
      (3)   If platted after June 14, 2010, and providing access to one or two
buildable lots of record, the easement shall be at least twenty-five feet wide
and the roadway shall be constructed in accordance with the driveway
construction standards as set forth in
Chapter 1025 of this Code.
      (4)   If platted after June 14, 2010, and providing access to three or
more buildable lots of record, the easement width shall be at least sixty-six
feet and the roadway pavement and related facilities within the easement shall
be constructed in accordance with the public street standards as set forth in
Chapter 1248 of this Code.
      (5)   If platted after June 14, 2010, the easement shall not provide
access between two publicly dedicated street rights-of-way unless part of a
planned unit development.
      (6)   If platted after June 14, 2010, the easement shall be subject to
covenants recorded against the title of each adjoining property that obligates
the property owner to maintain the roadway pavement and related facilities
within said easement, the wording of which shall be approved by the Village.
Failure to maintain pavement conditions within safe tolerances shall be subject
to Village property maintenance enforcement authority.
   (See Section
1268.02(c) for standards excluding private street easements and shared driveway
easements from lot area calculations.)
   (e)   Side lines of lots shall be approximately at right angles or radial to
the street line.
   (f)   Lots abutting or including a watercourse, drainageway, channel or
stream shall have additional minimum width or depth as required to provide an
adequate building site and to afford the minimum usable area required by the
Zoning Code for front, rear and side yards.
(Ord. 2003-21. Passed 6-23-03; Ord. 2005-33. Passed 9-12-05; Ord. 2010-19.
Passed 6-14-10.)
1246.06 PARKS, SCHOOLS AND PUBLIC AREAS.
   (a)   Where a proposed park, playground, school or other public use area,
shown in the Comprehensive Plan for the Village and adjacent unincorporated
areas, is located in whole or in part in a subdivision, the Plan Commission and
Council may require the dedication or reservation of such area, in whole or in
part, within the subdivision in those cases in which the Commission and Council
deem such requirement to be reasonable. However, in no case shall the total
amount of required public areas to be dedicated, including public streets,
exceed ten percent of the total gross acreage owned and controlled by one
developer.
   (b)   In the subdividing of any land within the Village, or within one and
one-half miles of the corporate limits, due regard shall be shown for all
natural features, such as tree growth, watercourses, etc., and for historic
spots.
1246.07 LOT COVERAGE IN R-1-A ONE-FAMILY DWELLING DISTRICT.
   The maximum lot coverage for one-family detached dwellings in the R-1-A One-
Family Dwelling District shall be twenty percent (20%) of the total area of the
lot. In calculating the lot coverage, both the footprint of the principal
dwelling and any accessory buildings shall be used.
(Ord. 1995-18. Passed 5-22-95; Ord. 2005-27. Passed 7-11-05.)
1246.08 MAXIMUM GROSS FLOOR AREA IN R-1-A ONE-FAMILY DWELLING DISTRICTS.
   (a)   The maximum gross floor area for one-family detached dwellings in the
R-1-A One-Family Dwelling Districts shall include:
      (1)   All above-ground living areas on all floors.
      (2)   Basements, if one-half or more of the floor to ceiling height of
the basement is above the average grade of the dwelling.
      (3)   Attic spaces where head room under flat ceilings is a minimum of
seven, feet-six inches, and the low point under the sloped ceilings is five
feet.
      (4)   Covered porches and balconies.
      (5)   Open two-story areas, two times.
      (6)   Garages, both attached and detached.
   (b)   The maximum gross floor area allowable for one-family detached
dwellings in the R-1-A One-Family Dwelling Districts shall be determined as
follows:
      (1)   Lots of one-half acre or less shall be allowed a maximum gross
floor area of twenty-three percent of the total area of the lot.
      (2)   Lots of one-half acre to two acres shall be allowed a maximum gross
floor area of twenty-two percent of the total area of the lot.
      (3)   Lots in excess of two acres shall be allowed a maximum gross floor
area of 21.5 percent of the total area of the lot.
   (c)   Before making the calculation set forth in subsection (b) hereof, the
actual floor area of the dwelling shall be reduced as follows:
      (1)   For lots of one-half acre or less in size, the floor area of the
dwelling shall be reduced by 750 square feet.
      (2)   For lots of more than one-half acre, but less than one acre, in
size, the floor area of the dwelling shall be reduced by 400 square feet.
(Ord. 1992-39. Passed 7-13-92; Ord. 2005-41. Passed 11-28-05; Ord. 2006-13.
Passed 3-13-06.)

1248.01 REQUIRED LAND IMPROVEMENTS.
   No subdivision of land shall be approved without a statement from the
Village Engineer stating that the improvements described in the subdivider's
plans and specifications, together with agreements, meet the minimum
requirements of all ordinances of the Village and comply with the provisions of
this chapter.
1248.02 SEWERS.
   (a)   If sanitary sewers and sewage treatment facilities are required or
installed, such sewers shall be installed to comply with specifications
established by the Village. Where private sewage disposal systems are
installed, they shall also comply with specifications established by the
Village.
   (b)   An adequate system of storm water drainage shall be constructed and
installed, consisting of natural watercourses, swales, storm sewers and other
necessary facilities in accordance with Village standards and specifications.
The storm water drainage system shall be separate and independent of any
sanitary sewerage system and shall be installed in accordance with sound
engineering standards.
   (c)   House services for sewerage shall be constructed to connect each lot
or building site with the utility service mains.
1248.03 STREETS.
   (a)   Grading.
      (1)   All stumps, trees that cannot be saved, boulders and similar items
in street rights of way shall be removed from the site by the contractor or
developer.
      (2)   Before any paving work is commenced, street grading shall be
properly completed and approved by the Village Engineer.
      (3)   After grading of streets is completed and approved, and before any
base course of the roadway pavement is laid, all of the underground work, such
as sewer and gas mains, house service connections therewith and all underground
conduits for electric and telephone lines, shall be completely installed in
place and approved by the Village Engineer.
   (b)   Dimensions. All streets shall conform to the following dimensions:
 
Type of Street          Dedicated Right-of Way Width Roadway Width
                        Conform to the Official      2-24 foot roadways divided
Primary or major street Village Map and in no        by a median strip
                        instance less than 100 feet
Secondary street        80 feet                      24 feet
Minor street            66 feet                      22 feet
Cul-de-sac              50 feet radius               22 feet
 
   (c)   Roadway Surface. Roadways shall be surfaced with concrete seven inches
thick or bituminous concrete not less than two inches thick over a base of
crushed stone or gravel not less than eight inches thick after compaction.
   (d)   Curbs and Gutters. Curbs and gutters, when required on minor
residential streets, shall be of the integral rolled-type unit, not less than
eighteen inches in overall width and not less than ten inches thick where the
curb abuts the street pavement. Curbs and gutters, when required, on primary or
secondary streets shall be installed in accordance with specifications
established by the Village Engineer.
   (e)   Storm Water Inlets. Storm water inlets shall be provided within the
roadway improvement at points specified by the Village Engineer.
   (f)   Curb Corners. All curb corners shall have a radii of not less than
fifteen feet and, at important intersections, not less than twenty-five feet.
   (g)   Standards Outside Corporate Limits. In subdivisions outside the
corporate area, but within the one and one-half mile area, roadway improvements
shall conform to the same standards as required of subdivisions within the
corporate area. The curb and gutter may be omitted when recommended by the Plan
Commission and Council.
   (h)   Side Strips. Side strips are required on both sides of all streets.
They shall be graded and prepared for seeding by the subdivider with at least
four inches of topsoil. Median strips shall be considered as side strips unless
paved.
   (i)   Trees. Trees shall be planted along all streets where trees do not
exist. Trees shall have a trunk diameter, measured twelve inches above the
ground, of not less than two and one-half inches, and shall be spaced not more
than fifty feet apart. This requirement will be satisfied if an equivalent
number of trees of the same size or larger is planted in a naturalistic manner
in the front yards of the adjoining lots. The plantings shall be restricted and
approved by the Plan Commission. Chinese elm, box elder, willow, poplar and
similar fast-growing brittle-wood species are prohibited. Trees shall be
maintained and dead trees replaced by the subdivider for a period of two years
after initial planting.
   (j)   Street Signs. Street signs shall be provided by the subdivider in
accordance with Village standards and specifications and shall be located so as
to identify every street within the boundaries of the subdivision.
   (k)   Lighting. Provision shall be made for lighting of street intersections
within the proposed subdivision with the plans for such installation subject to
Village approval.
   (l)   Private Street Guard Houses and Gates. For permanent access easements
platted after January 1, 2004 that provide access to three or more lots and
that comply with the requirements of Section
1246.05(d)(4), (5) and (6) of this Code, a guard house and gate structures
shall be permitted within the access easement subject to compliance with the
following standards:
      (1)   The guard house shall be no greater than twelve feet in height and
the gate structure shall be no greater than eight feet in height, as measured
from the road pavement in line with the guard house and gate.
      (2)   The guard house structure shall be no closer than three feet to the
edge of the road pavement in the easement.
      (3)   The guard house and gate structures shall be no less than ten
lateral feet or more away from water mains, sanitary sewer mains, storm sewers,
and drainage swales.
      (4)   The guard house and gate structures shall be setback at least
thirty feet from the edge of pavement of any publicly dedicated street, to
allow for stacking or space for stopped vehicles waiting to get through the
gate.
      (5)   The gate structure shall have safety lighting or reflectors, so
vehicle drivers can see if the gate is closed at night or weather conditions
limiting visibility.
      (6)   The gate structure shall be operable at all times by on-site
personnel, or on-site manual override device, or a remote control device
operable by public service personnel, including but not limited to Village
employees.
      (7)   The guard house and gate structures shall be subject to covenants
recorded against the title to all properties that are accessible through the
guard house and gate structures, that obligate the property owners to maintain
the guard house and gate structures, the wording of which shall be subject to
approval by the Village. Failure to maintain said guard house and gate
structures shall be subject to Village property maintenance enforcement
authority.
(Ord. 2010-20. Passed 6-14-10.)
1248.04 PUBLIC UTILITIES.
   (a)   All utility distribution lines for telephone, electric and gas service
in the subdivision shall be placed underground. Installation of such facilities
shall be made in compliance .with the applicable orders, rules and regulations
of the Illinois Commerce Commission now or hereafter effective. The subdivider
shall be responsible for compliance with rules and regulations of any public
utility whose service will be required for the subdivision, which rules and
regulations relate to the provision of such facilities and which rules and
regulations are now effective or hereafter become effective and are filed with
such Commission pursuant to the Illinois Public Utilities Act.
   (b)   Underground telephone, electric and gas service shall be placed within
easements or dedicated public ways in a manner which will not conflict with
other underground services. Further, all transformer boxes shall be located so
as not to be unsightly or hazardous to the public.
1248.05 AS-BUILT PLANS.
   Upon completion of the installation of improvements in a subdivision, one
set of tracings on cloth or equal, suitable for use in reproduction, which
shows all improvements as actually installed in the field, shall be filed with
the Village Engineer.

CHAPTER 1260 - GENERAL PROVISIONS AND DEFINITIONS

1220
